header.title: The Scroll of Set - April 1993
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Setianism, Left-Hand Path

central_thesis: The Scroll of Set, April 1993 issue, serves as a comprehensive internal publication for the Temple of Set, articulating and advancing its core philosophy of Xeper (self-creation) through diverse articles covering ontological discussions, practical magical applications, community organization (Pylons, Glinda), and critical examinations of external concepts like Karma. It consistently emphasizes the distinctiveness of the Left-Hand Path, individual will, and the embrace of darkness and mystery for personal and collective evolution within the ongoing Æon of Set.

structure_content.summary: A poetic and philosophical invocation to Set, emphasizing individual transformation (Xeper), the embrace of darkness, and rejection of conventional morality to achieve a 'new æon' through intellectual analysis and instinct.
A short poem depicting the transformation of Setians, the liberation of ancient entities, and the emergence of a 'resplendent dark' Earth under a new, liberated, and potentially chaotic æon.

structure_content.chapter_title: Trafficking in Tigers, Rhinos Fosters Extinction
structure_content.summary: An article (included by special request) highlighting the devastating impact of illegal trade in tiger bones and rhino horns, calling for boycotts of related products.

Chronicles the establishment and growth of the Set-Amentet Pylon, detailing meetings, discussions, and group workings that exemplify the unique individuality and Xeper process within the Pylon structure.

A critical deconstruction of the Western concept of Karma, arguing it is a misconception rooted in Puritan theology, advocating for self-made justice in a 'nasty, brutal, and unfair' universe, and dismissing reincarnation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Role Models, Runa, and the Limit
structure_content.summary: Discusses the use of 'Runa' (what worked before can work again) and various types of role models (divine, hero, living, fictional) for achieving Xeper, emphasizing 'limitation' as crucial for self-definition and separation in the Left-Hand Path.

Explores the Roman Ritual of Exorcism as inspiration for Left-Hand Path (LBM) destruction workings, focusing on creating an 'alien presence' to affect individuals at their core, distinguishing it from Greater Black Magic (GBM).
A reflection on a previous poem, connecting its themes to Crowley and the survival of symbols, further exploring desire and will within Xeper, and the management of 'control programs' or habits.
Announcements of recent advancements (II° recognition) within the Temple of Set, highlighting individual achievements and the progress of the 'Black Flame'.
A review of the Kalevala Pylon's newsletter, 'Iku-Turso,' praising its content, artwork, and contributions to Setian philosophy, including discussions on Xeper, Remanifestation, and being Awake.
Discusses the significance of a magical cycle ('ÆS Working II') for the Temple of Set, involving decentralization and 'de-Satanization,' encouraging members to embrace this new era.

structure_content.chapter_title: You Know You're a Setian When...
structure_content.summary: A humorous list of characteristics and behaviors common among Setians, reflecting their unique lifestyle and philosophical inclinations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Solomon and the Dæmons of the Eastern Quarter
structure_content.summary: Part I of an account from the entity Bune, detailing King Solomon's capture of 72 dæmons, their nature as ancient 'Chaos spirits,' and the role of Lemurians in teaching magic.

An exploration of ancient Khemnu ('City of Eight'), its primordial deities (neters), and its connections to Lovecraftian horror and a 'Black Priesthood' teaching Xeper through 'controlled folly' and 'rapid Self Gnosis'.

A philosophical discourse defining ontology and arguing for a Setian preference for dualism, critiquing idealist and materialist extremes, and asserting that the 'phenomenon of being' is beyond materialistic reduction, central to the Gift of Set.

Nine reinterpretations of biblical beatitudes from a Left-Hand Path perspective, blessing those who embrace Setian values like reconciling 'beast and gods,' reversing the Lie, and becoming 'True Nosferatu'.

Details the modernization of the Pylon system within the Temple of Set, outlining requirements, guidelines for formation and function, and the Pylon's role in organizational structure and member interaction.

An update on the Temple's computer bulletin board system, Glinda, and its integration with FidoNet for improved accessibility, information exchange, and participation in occult-related 'echoes' for Setians worldwide.

key_concepts.definition: The central Setian concept of self-creation, self-transformation, and becoming more than one was, often framed as the goal of the Left-Hand Path.
The continuous process of surpassing and reforming one's being, a cyclical yet evolutionary aspect of Xeper.

A philosophical and magical orientation emphasizing individual will, self-deification, and a rejection of external authorities or conventional societal norms, in contrast to seeking union with a transcendent whole.
In a Setian context, a practical, operative approach to reality that transcends conditioned perceptions and actively shapes one's existence and environment.
A localized, self-organizing group within the Temple of Set, designed for members to interact, collaborate, and deepen their Setian studies and practices.
The Temple of Set's official electronic bulletin board system, serving as a central hub for communication, information sharing, and archival documents for its global membership.
A principle suggesting that methods or actions that have proven effective in the past for specific magical or transformational goals can be successfully reapplied.
A philosophical concept within the LHP, arguing that self-imposed boundaries or definitions are essential for separating, defining, and strengthening the individual self.

Ancient, conscious spirits with specific skills, some historically associated with grimoire traditions (e.g., King Solomon), whose interactions with magicians are influenced by the magician's level of awareness and development.

An ancient Egyptian sacred site associated with primordial deities (neters) representing fundamental cosmic forces like primeval waters, darkness, and eternal existence, linked to a 'Black Priesthood' focused on transformative gnosis.
The subjective, inner experience and consciousness of existence that is unique to each individual, considered beyond the scope of materialistic reductionism and central to the 'Gift of Set'.
The current magical epoch, characterized by a shift in consciousness, the re-evaluation of established paradigms, and an emphasis on individual self-overcoming and transformation.

practical_system.description: The practical system elucidated in this collection is centered on individual self-transformation (Xeper) through the conscious application of will, intellectual rigor, and instinctual engagement, within the Left-Hand Path framework. It involves actively seeking confrontation with the unknown, embracing the 'beast' within, and distinguishing oneself from conventional reality. The system encourages both solitary and communal magical practices, supported by organizational structures like Pylons and digital tools like Glinda.
tools: Personal Will and Desire: The primary operative forces for self-creation and change.
Intellectual Analysis and Instinct: Methods for gaining gnosis and guiding practical application.
Role Models: Archetypal figures (divine, heroic) and living exemplars for learning and applying principles to one's own Xeper.
Pylons: Communal structures for shared study, discussion, and collective magical workings, providing mutual support.
Glinda: A digital communication platform for information exchange, accessing Temple documents, and participating in occult discussions.
'C Factor' (Black Magic): A specific approach to magic within Setianism, emphasizing practical, operative results and transcending conditioned reality.
Sacred Symbols and Sigils: Visual and conceptual representations used in dæmonic interaction and personal workings.
rituals: Group Working (collaborative magical operations, e.g., themed around Ma'at).
Left-Hand Path (LBM) Destruction Workings (inspired by exorcism rites, designed to create an 'alien presence' for targeted influence).
Evocation/Interaction with Dæmons (engaging ancient spirits, understanding their skills and nature).
Self-Initiatory Practices (individualized methods for Xeper and Remanifestation, often involving introspection and the application of philosophical insights).

relevant_quotes.text: Beloved Set, I spring from the poetry of your ancient heart. I hold your sacred mystery of death and the unleashed liquid lightning of your passion. I drink in solitude of your splendor, and celebrate its ecstasy with those of my kind.
immortal essence wills for this Earth the death which births the victorious cry of a new æon.
The universe is a nasty, brutal, and unfair place. The only justice which exists within it is that which we make.

The notion of limitation is essential. We seek separation of the self from the surrounding environment and transformation of it according to innate patterns hidden within. The choice of role model is one of the best ways to limit and therefore define the self.
Setian philosophy/Satanism can never become a mass movement, partly because of the prejudices due to our upbringing and the thought models that society has given us.
The phenomenon of being - a result of psychecentric consciousness and therefore a part of the Gift of Set - that materialistic reductionism cannot touch.

critical_analysis.relevance: The Scroll of Set, April 1993, is highly relevant as a foundational document for understanding the ongoing philosophical and practical evolution of the Temple of Set during a period of significant internal change, including 'de-Satanization' and decentralization. It provides invaluable insight into how Setian principles like Xeper are applied to individual development, community building, and magical practice. The articles demonstrate a rigorous intellectual engagement with both occult traditions and external philosophical concepts, positioning Setianism as a distinct and evolving Left-Hand Path.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Primarily current and prospective Initiates of the Temple of Set. The content assumes familiarity with Setian terminology, concepts, and organizational structures. It functions as an informative, philosophical, and practical guide for members seeking to deepen their understanding, participate in the community, and advance their personal magical workings within the Setian framework.
